abstract_summ: The variables of gender, age, basic diseases, mechanical ventilation and complications were included in the unconditional Logistic regression analysis, which showed that gender [odds ratio (OR) = 2.852, 95% confidence interval (95%CI) was 0.122-66.694], age (OR = 3.257, 95%CI was 0.466-18.584), coronary heart disease (OR = 7.337, 95%CI was 0.227-87.021), hypertension (OR = 5.517, 95%CI was 0.258-65.024) and concurrent myocardial damage (OR = 7.322, 95%CI was 0.278-95.020) and thrombocytopenia (OR = 3.968, 95%CI was 0.325-35.549) were independent risk factors for death in patients with severe and critical COVID-19 during hospitalization.Conclusions Diabetes mellitus is associated with increased disease severity and a higher risk of mortality in patients with COVID-19.BACKGROUND: Older age and elevated d-dimer are reported risk factors for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).The death prediction model is constructed by gender, age, basic diseases with coronary heart disease and hypertension, concurrent myocardial damage and thrombocytopenia, which has certain predictive value for the death of patients with severe or critical COVID-19.A pandemic named coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) outbroke in China since December 2019.According to the risk factors, the death prediction model was constructed and ROC curve was analyzed, which showed that the area under ROC curve (AUC) of death prediction model for predicting the mortality of patients with severe and critical COVID-19 during hospitalization was 0.804, the sensitivity was 83.8%, and the specificity was 82.3%.CONCLUSIONS Various risk factors are associated with the death of severe or critical COVID-19 patients, such as gender, age, basic diseases and complications.
title_summ: Coronavirus disease 2019 in elderly patients: Characteristics and prognostic factors based on 4-week follow-upAssociation of Diabetes Mellitus with Disease Severity and Prognosis in COVID-19: A Retrospective Cohort StudyPredictors of fatality including radiographic findings in adults with COVID-19The risk factors associated with MERS-CoV patient fatality: A global surveyRisk factors and pathogenic microorganism characteristics for pneumonia in convalescent patients with stroke: A retrospective study of 380 patients from a rehabilitation hospital: A retrospective study of risk factors and pathogenic microorganism characteristics for pneumonia in convalescent patients with strokeA novel risk score to predict diagnosis with Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID‐19) in suspected patients: A retrospective, multi‐center, observational study[Logistic regression analysis of death risk factors of patients with severe and critical coronavirus disease 2019 and their predictive value].Risk factors analysis and nomogram construction of non-survivors in critical patients with COVID-19.Risk assessment of progression to severe conditions for patients with COVID-19 pneumonia: a single-center retrospective studyPrognostic factors for COVID-19 pneumonia progression to severe symptom based on the earlier clinical features: a retrospective analysisComorbid Diabetes Mellitus was Associated with Poorer Prognosis in Patients with COVID-19: A Retrospective Cohort StudyRadiographic Findings and other Predictors in Adults with Covid-19COVID-19 Outcomes in 4712 consecutively confirmed SARS-CoV2 cases in the city of Madrid.
title_abstract_phrases: The variables of gender, age, basic diseases, mechanical ventilation and complications were included in the unconditional Logistic regression analysis, which showed that gender [odds ratio (OR) = 2.852, 95% confidence interval (95%CI) was 0.122-66.694], age (OR = 3.257, 95%CI was 0.466-18.584), coronary heart disease (OR = 7.337, 95%CI was 0.227-87.021), hypertension (OR = 5.517, 95%CI was 0.258-65.024) and concurrent myocardial damage (OR = 7.322, 95%CI was 0.278-95.020) and thrombocytopenia (OR = 3.968, 95%CI was 0.325-35.549) were independent risk factors for death in patients with severe and critical COVID-19 during hospitalization.Conclusions Diabetes mellitus is associated with increased disease severity and a higher risk of mortality in patients with COVID-19.Predictors of fatality including radiographic findings in adults with COVID-19BACKGROUND: Older age and elevated d-dimer are reported risk factors for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).The death prediction model is constructed by gender, age, basic diseases with coronary heart disease and hypertension, concurrent myocardial damage and thrombocytopenia, which has certain predictive value for the death of patients with severe or critical COVID-19.Risk factors analysis and nomogram construction of non-survivors in critical patients with COVID-19.A pandemic named coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) outbroke in China since December 2019.[Logistic regression analysis of death risk factors of patients with severe and critical coronavirus disease 2019 and their predictive value].OBJECTIVE To analyze the risk factors of death in patients with severe and critical coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and their predictive value.This index was 1.43 [95% CI: 1.06–1.92] for Saudi patients in comparison to non-Saudi; 1.76 [95% CI: 1.39–2.22] for patient with comorbidity in comparison to those without comorbidity; 0.58 [95% CI: 0.44–0.75] for those who had close contact to a camel in the past 14 days and 0.42 [95% CI: 0.31–0.57] for patients with >14 days with onset of signs and hospital admission compared to patients with ≤14 days.
